natural problem: Suppose that we are given 40 points equally spaced around the perimeter of a square, so that four of them are located at the vertices and the remaining points divide each side into ten congruent segments.  If $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are chosen to be any three of these points which are not collinear, then how many different possible positions are there for the centroid of $\triangle PQR$?
natural solution: Without loss of generality, assume that our square has vertices at $(0,0)$, $(10,0)$, $(10,10)$, and $(0,10)$ in the coordinate plane, so that the 40 equally spaced points are exactly those points along the perimeter of this square with integral coordinates.

We first note that if $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are three of these points which are not collinear, then the centroid of $\triangle PQR$ must lie in the interior of the square, not along one of its sides. And secondly, we recall that the coordinates of the centroid are found by averaging the coordinates of $P$, $Q$, and $R$.
Therefore the coordinates of the centroid must be of the form $\left(\frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3}\right)$ where $m$ and $n$ are integers with $1\le m,n\le 29$.

To show that every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid, we divide into cases. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(0,0)$, $(m,0)$, and $(0,n)$.

If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 10,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(0,n)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(10,n)$.

If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(0,10)$. If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(10,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(m - 10,10)$.

If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,n - 10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(0,10)$, and $(m,10)$.

If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(m - 10,10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,10)$, $(10,n - 20)$, and $(10,10)$.
Thus, every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid. This means that there are $29^2=\boxed{841}$ positions for the centroid.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes points :: "int set"
and P Q R :: int
assumes h0 : "card points = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> p q r . {p, q, r} \<subseteq> points \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> p \<noteq> r \<and> q \<noteq> r \<and> \<not> collinear p q r \<longrightarrow> centroid {p, q, r} \<in> points"
shows  "card (centroids points) = 841"
a_0.formal solution:

theorem
fixes points :: "int set"
and P Q R :: int
assumes h0 : "card points = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> p q r . {p, q, r} \<subseteq> points \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> p \<noteq> r \<and> q \<noteq> r \<and> \<not> collinear p q r \<longrightarrow> centroid {p, q, r} \<in> points"
shows  "card (centroids points) = 841"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: We have a set of 40 distinct points. For any three non-collinear points (no three points are on the same line) taken from the set, the centroid of the triangle formed by these three points is also in the set. How many different centroids can be formed this way? The final answer is 841.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes points :: "nat"
and square :: "nat \<Rightarrow> 'a::euclidean_space"
and P Q R :: "'a"
and centroid :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "points = 40"
and h1 : "four_points_on_vertices square"
and h2 : "remaining_points_divide_sides square"
and h3 : "\<forall>P Q R. non_collinear P Q R square \<longrightarrow> centroid_positions P Q R square = centroid"
shows  "centroid = 841"
a_1.formal solution:

theorem
fixes points :: "nat"
and square :: "nat \<Rightarrow> 'a::euclidean_space"
and P Q R :: "'a"
and centroid :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "points = 40"
and h1 : "four_points_on_vertices square"
and h2 : "remaining_points_divide_sides square"
and h3 : "\<forall>P Q R. non_collinear P Q R square \<longrightarrow> centroid_positions P Q R square = centroid"
shows  "centroid = 841"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a square with 40 points, 4 of which are on the vertices and the remaining points divide the sides of the square. If for any non-collinear points P, Q, R on the square, their centroid positions sum up to a value called "centroid". Find the value of "centroid". The final answer is 841.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes points :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "points 40 4 = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>P Q R. \<not> collinear P Q R"
and h2 : "card {G | P Q R G. centroid G P Q R} = 841"
shows  "possible_centroid_positions = 841"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we are given 40 points equally spaced around the perimeter of a square, so that four of them are located at the vertices and the remaining points divide each side into ten congruent segments.  If $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are chosen to be any three of these points which are not collinear, then how many different possible positions are there for the centroid of $\triangle PQR$? The final Answer is 841
 ### Proof
 Without loss of generality, assume that our square has vertices at $(0,0)$, $(10,0)$, $(10,10)$, and $(0,10)$ in the coordinate plane, so that the 40 equally spaced points are exactly those points along the perimeter of this square with integral coordinates.
 We first note that if $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are three of these points which are not collinear, then the centroid of $\triangle PQR$ must lie in the interior of the square, not along one of its sides. And secondly, we recall that the coordinates of the centroid are found by averaging the coordinates of $P$, $Q$, and $R$.

 To show that every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid, we divide into cases. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(0,0)$, $(m,0)$, and $(0,n)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 10,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(0,n)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(10,n)$.
 If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(0,10)$. If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(10,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(m - 10,10)$.
 If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,n - 10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(0,10)$, and $(m,10)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(m - 10,10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,10)$, $(10,n - 20)$, and $(10,10)$.
 Thus, every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid. This means that there are $29^2=\boxed{841}$ positions for the centroid.
 *)

theorem
fixes points :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "points 40 4 = 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>P Q R. \<not> collinear P Q R"
and h2 : "card {G | P Q R G. centroid G P Q R} = 841"
shows  "possible_centroid_positions = 841"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Suppose there is a function "points" that assigns a point value to each combination of 40 points and 4 points. The value assigned to the combination of 40 and 4 is 10. If no three points are collinear and there are 841 unique centroids of the triangles formed by these points, determine the number of possible centroid positions. The final answer is 841.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes square_points :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (real * real)"
assumes h0 : "card {n. square_points n} = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i < 40 \<and> i \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> segment (square_points i) (square_points (i + 1)) = segment (square_points 0) (square_points 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i < 40 \<longrightarrow> collinear {square_points i, square_points (i + 1), square_points (i + 2)}"
and h3 : "vertices = {square_points 0, square_points 10, square_points 20, square_points 30}"
and h4 : "congruent_segments = (\<Union>i<40. {square_points i, square_points (i + 1)})"
and h5 : "triangle = {P, Q, R}. P \<in> congruent_segments \<and> Q \<in> congruent_segments \<and> R \<in> congruent_segments \<and> \<not> collinear {P, Q, R}"
and h6 : "centroid_positions = {C. \<exists> P Q R. triangle P Q R \<and> centroid C P Q R}"
shows  "card centroid_positions = 841"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we are given 40 points equally spaced around the perimeter of a square, so that four of them are located at the vertices and the remaining points divide each side into ten congruent segments.  If $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are chosen to be any three of these points which are not collinear, then how many different possible positions are there for the centroid of $\triangle PQR$? The final Answer is 841
 ### Proof
 Without loss of generality, assume that our square has vertices at $(0,0)$, $(10,0)$, $(10,10)$, and $(0,10)$ in the coordinate plane, so that the 40 equally spaced points are exactly those points along the perimeter of this square with integral coordinates.
 We first note that if $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are three of these points which are not collinear, then the centroid of $\triangle PQR$ must lie in the interior of the square, not along one of its sides. And secondly, we recall that the coordinates of the centroid are found by averaging the coordinates of $P$, $Q$, and $R$.
 Therefore the coordinates of the centroid must be of the form $\left(\frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3}\right)$ where $m$ and $n$ are integers with $1\le m,n\le 29$.
 To show that every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid, we divide into cases. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(0,0)$, $(m,0)$, and $(0,n)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 10,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(0,n)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(10,n)$.
 If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(0,10)$. If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(10,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(m - 10,10)$.
 If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,n - 10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(0,10)$, and $(m,10)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(m - 10,10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,10)$, $(10,n - 20)$, and $(10,10)$.
 Thus, every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid. This means that there are $29^2=\boxed{841}$ positions for the centroid.
 *)

theorem
fixes square_points :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (real * real)"
assumes h0 : "card {n. square_points n} = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i < 40 \<and> i \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> segment (square_points i) (square_points (i + 1)) = segment (square_points 0) (square_points 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i < 40 \<longrightarrow> collinear {square_points i, square_points (i + 1), square_points (i + 2)}"
and h3 : "vertices = {square_points 0, square_points 10, square_points 20, square_points 30}"
and h4 : "congruent_segments = (\<Union>i<40. {square_points i, square_points (i + 1)})"
and h5 : "triangle = {P, Q, R}. P \<in> congruent_segments \<and> Q \<in> congruent_segments \<and> R \<in> congruent_segments \<and> \<not> collinear {P, Q, R}"
and h6 : "centroid_positions = {C. \<exists> P Q R. triangle P Q R \<and> centroid C P Q R}"
shows  "card centroid_positions = 841"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are 40 points on a square, numbered from 0 to 39. The distance between any two consecutive points, except for point 0, is equal to the distance between points 0 and 1. All three consecutive points are collinear. The square has vertices at points 0, 10, 20, and 30. The set of congruent segments consists of all segments connecting any two consecutive points. There is a triangle formed by three non-collinear points P, Q, and R from the set of congruent segments. There is a set of centroid positions, each of which is the centroid of a triangle with vertices P, Q, and R. How many centroid positions are there? The final answer is 841.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes points :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (real * real)"
assumes h0 : "card {i. i \<in> {1..40} \<and> points i \<noteq> (0, 0) \<and> points i \<noteq> (1, 0) \<and> points i \<noteq> (0, 1) \<and> points i \<noteq> (1, 1)} = 36"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<in> {1..40} \<and> j \<in> {1..40} \<longrightarrow> \<not> collinear (points i) (points j) (points (if j + 1 > 40 then 1 else j + 1))"
and h2 : "card {C. \<exists>P Q R. P \<noteq> Q \<and> P \<noteq> R \<and> Q \<noteq> R \<and> centroid P Q R = C} = 841"
shows  "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..40} \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b. a \<noteq> b \<and> (\<exists> x y. centroid (points i) (points a) (points b) = (x, y)))"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we are given 40 points equally spaced around the perimeter of a square, so that four of them are located at the vertices and the remaining points divide each side into ten congruent segments.  If $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are chosen to be any three of these points which are not collinear, then how many different possible positions are there for the centroid of $\triangle PQR$? The final Answer is 841
 ### Proof
 Without loss of generality, assume that our square has vertices at $(0,0)$, $(10,0)$, $(10,10)$, and $(0,10)$ in the coordinate plane, so that the 40 equally spaced points are exactly those points along the perimeter of this square with integral coordinates.
 We first note that if $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are three of these points which are not collinear, then the centroid of $\triangle PQR$ must lie in the interior of the square, not along one of its sides. And secondly, we recall that the coordinates of the centroid are found by averaging the coordinates of $P$, $Q$, and $R$.
 Therefore the coordinates of the centroid must be of the form $\left(\frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3}\right)$ where $m$ and $n$ are integers with $1\le m,n\le 29$.
 To show that every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid, we divide into cases. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(0,0)$, $(m,0)$, and $(0,n)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 10,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(0,n)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(10,n)$.
 If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(0,10)$. If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(10,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(m - 10,10)$.
 If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,n - 10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(0,10)$, and $(m,10)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(m - 10,10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,10)$, $(10,n - 20)$, and $(10,10)$.
 Thus, every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid. This means that there are $29^2=\boxed{841}$ positions for the centroid.
 *)

theorem
fixes points :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (real * real)"
assumes h0 : "card {i. i \<in> {1..40} \<and> points i \<noteq> (0, 0) \<and> points i \<noteq> (1, 0) \<and> points i \<noteq> (0, 1) \<and> points i \<noteq> (1, 1)} = 36"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<in> {1..40} \<and> j \<in> {1..40} \<longrightarrow> \<not> collinear (points i) (points j) (points (if j + 1 > 40 then 1 else j + 1))"
and h2 : "card {C. \<exists>P Q R. P \<noteq> Q \<and> P \<noteq> R \<and> Q \<noteq> R \<and> centroid P Q R = C} = 841"
shows  "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..40} \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> a b. a \<noteq> b \<and> (\<exists> x y. centroid (points i) (points a) (points b) = (x, y)))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: There are 40 points in total, and 4 of them are (0,0), (1,0), (0,1), and (1,1), leaving 36 other distinct points. No three consecutive points in the set are collinear. How many different centroids can be formed by selecting three distinct points from the set? The final answer is 841.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes points :: "nat set" and centroid_positions :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card points = 40"
and h1 : "four_points_at_vertices points"
and h2 : "equally_spaced_points points"
and h3 : "positions_centroid points centroid_positions"
shows  "card centroid_positions = 841"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we are given 40 points equally spaced around the perimeter of a square, so that four of them are located at the vertices and the remaining points divide each side into ten congruent segments.  If $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are chosen to be any three of these points which are not collinear, then how many different possible positions are there for the centroid of $\triangle PQR$? The final Answer is 841

 Without loss of generality, assume that our square has vertices at $(0,0)$, $(10,0)$, $(10,10)$, and $(0,10)$ in the coordinate plane, so that the 40 equally spaced points are exactly those points along the perimeter of this square with integral coordinates.

And secondly, we recall that the coordinates of the centroid are found by averaging the coordinates of $P$, $Q$, and $R$.
 Therefore the coordinates of the centroid must be of the form $\left(\frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3}\right)$ where $m$ and $n$ are integers with $1\le m,n\le 29$.
 To show that every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid, we divide into cases. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(0,0)$, $(m,0)$, and $(0,n)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 10,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(0,n)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(10,n)$.
 If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(0,10)$. If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(10,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(m - 10,10)$.
 If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,n - 10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(0,10)$, and $(m,10)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(m - 10,10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,10)$, $(10,n - 20)$, and $(10,10)$.
 Thus, every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid. This means that there are $29^2=\boxed{841}$ positions for the centroid.
 *)

theorem
fixes points :: "nat set" and centroid_positions :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card points = 40"
and h1 : "four_points_at_vertices points"
and h2 : "equally_spaced_points points"
and h3 : "positions_centroid points centroid_positions"
shows  "card centroid_positions = 841"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A set of points has 40 equally spaced points, including four points at the vertices of a square. Find the number of possible positions for the centroid of the set of points. The final answer is 841.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes points :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (real * real)"
and P Q R :: "nat"
and centroid :: "(real * real) set"
assumes h0 : "card {points i | i. i \<in> {1..40}} = 40"
and h1 : "four_points_at_vertices points"
and h2 : "congruent_segments points"
and h3 : "\<forall>P Q R. P \<noteq> Q \<and> Q \<noteq> R \<and> P \<noteq> R \<and> non_collinear (points P) (points Q) (points R) \<longrightarrow> centroid (points P) (points Q) (points R) \<in> centroid"
shows  "card centroid = 841"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we are given 40 points equally spaced around the perimeter of a square, so that four of them are located at the vertices and the remaining points divide each side into ten congruent segments.  If $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are chosen to be any three of these points which are not collinear, then how many different possible positions are there for the centroid of $\triangle PQR$? The final Answer is 841
 ### Proof
 Without loss of generality, assume that our square has vertices at $(0,0)$, $(10,0)$, $(10,10)$, and $(0,10)$ in the coordinate plane, so that the 40 equally spaced points are exactly those points along the perimeter of this square with integral coordinates.
 We first note that if $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are three of these points which are not collinear, then the centroid of $\triangle PQR$ must lie in the interior of the square, not along one of its sides. And secondly, we recall that the coordinates of the centroid are found by averaging the coordinates of $P$, $Q$, and $R$.
 Therefore the coordinates of the centroid must be of the form $\left(\frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3}\right)$ where $m$ and $n$ are integers with $1\le m,n\le 29$.
 To show that every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid, we divide into cases. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(0,0)$, $(m,0)$, and $(0,n)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 10,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(0,n)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(10,n)$.
 If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(0,10)$. If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(10,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(m - 10,10)$.
 If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,n - 10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(0,10)$, and $(m,10)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(m - 10,10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,10)$, $(10,n - 20)$, and $(10,10)$.
 Thus, every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid. This means that there are $29^2=\boxed{841}$ positions for the centroid.
 *)

theorem
fixes points :: "nat \<Rightarrow> (real * real)"
and P Q R :: "nat"
and centroid :: "(real * real) set"
assumes h0 : "card {points i | i. i \<in> {1..40}} = 40"
and h1 : "four_points_at_vertices points"
and h2 : "congruent_segments points"
and h3 : "\<forall>P Q R. P \<noteq> Q \<and> Q \<noteq> R \<and> P \<noteq> R \<and> non_collinear (points P) (points Q) (points R) \<longrightarrow> centroid (points P) (points Q) (points R) \<in> centroid"
shows  "card centroid = 841"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a set of 40 distinct points, four points are at the vertices of a rectangle, and all other points are located such that the line segments connecting any two non-collinear points are congruent. If there are 841 distinct centroids that can be formed by taking the centroid of any non-collinear triple of points, how many points are there in the set? The final answer is 40.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes points :: nat and square :: "('a::euclidean_space) set"
assumes h0 : "points = 40"
and h1 : "square \<noteq> {}"
and h2 : "card square = 4"
and h3 : "\<forall>side \<in> square. card (side \<inter> {P, Q, R}) \<ge> 1"
and h4 : "\<exists>!centroid. centroid_of {P, Q, R} centroid"
shows  "card {centroid. \<exists>P Q R. \<not> collinear P Q R \<and> centroid_of {P, Q, R} centroid} = 841"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

And secondly, we recall that the coordinates of the centroid are found by averaging the coordinates of $P$, $Q$, and $R$.

 To show that every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid, we divide into cases. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(0,0)$, $(m,0)$, and $(0,n)$.

 If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,n - 10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(0,10)$, and $(m,10)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(m - 10,10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,10)$, $(10,n - 20)$, and $(10,10)$.
 Thus, every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid. This means that there are $29^2=\boxed{841}$ positions for the centroid.
 *)

theorem
fixes points :: nat and square :: "('a::euclidean_space) set"
assumes h0 : "points = 40"
and h1 : "square \<noteq> {}"
and h2 : "card square = 4"
and h3 : "\<forall>side \<in> square. card (side \<inter> {P, Q, R}) \<ge> 1"
and h4 : "\<exists>!centroid. centroid_of {P, Q, R} centroid"
shows  "card {centroid. \<exists>P Q R. \<not> collinear P Q R \<and> centroid_of {P, Q, R} centroid} = 841"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a square with 40 points in total, and each side of the square has at least one point from the set {P, Q, R}, find the number of distinct centroids that can be formed from non-collinear points P, Q, and R. The final answer is 841.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes points :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "points = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> P Q R. P \<noteq> Q \<and> Q \<noteq> R \<and> P \<noteq> R \<longrightarrow> \<not> collinear P Q R"
shows  "card {G. \<exists> P Q R. centroid P Q R = G} = 841"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we are given 40 points equally spaced around the perimeter of a square, so that four of them are located at the vertices and the remaining points divide each side into ten congruent segments.  If $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are chosen to be any three of these points which are not collinear, then how many different possible positions are there for the centroid of $\triangle PQR$? The final Answer is 841

And secondly, we recall that the coordinates of the centroid are found by averaging the coordinates of $P$, $Q$, and $R$.

 To show that every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid, we divide into cases. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(0,0)$, $(m,0)$, and $(0,n)$.

 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(m - 10,10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,10)$, $(10,n - 20)$, and $(10,10)$.
 Thus, every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid. This means that there are $29^2=\boxed{841}$ positions for the centroid.
 *)

theorem 
fixes points :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "points = 40"
and h1 : "\<forall> P Q R. P \<noteq> Q \<and> Q \<noteq> R \<and> P \<noteq> R \<longrightarrow> \<not> collinear P Q R"
shows  "card {G. \<exists> P Q R. centroid P Q R = G} = 841"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A total of 40 distinct points are given. No three of these points are collinear. How many unique centroids can be formed from all possible combinations of these points? The final answer is 841.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P Q R :: "real*real"
and A :: "(real*real) set"
assumes h0 : "A = {(x,y). x in {0,0.1,..,1} & y in {0,0.1,..,1}}"
and h1 : "card A = 40"
and h2 : "{P,Q,R} ⊆ A"
and h3 : "P ≠ Q ∧ Q ≠ R ∧ R ≠ P"
and h4 : "collinear {P,Q,R} = False"
shows  "card {G. ∃ P Q R in A. P ≠ Q ∧ Q ≠ R ∧ R ≠ P ∧ collinear {P,Q,R} = False ∧ centroid {P,Q,R} = G} = 841"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we are given 40 points equally spaced around the perimeter of a square, so that four of them are located at the vertices and the remaining points divide each side into ten congruent segments.  If $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are chosen to be any three of these points which are not collinear, then how many different possible positions are there for the centroid of $\triangle PQR$? The final Answer is 841
 ### Proof
 Without loss of generality, assume that our square has vertices at $(0,0)$, $(10,0)$, $(10,10)$, and $(0,10)$ in the coordinate plane, so that the 40 equally spaced points are exactly those points along the perimeter of this square with integral coordinates.
 We first note that if $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are three of these points which are not collinear, then the centroid of $\triangle PQR$ must lie in the interior of the square, not along one of its sides. And secondly, we recall that the coordinates of the centroid are found by averaging the coordinates of $P$, $Q$, and $R$.
 Therefore the coordinates of the centroid must be of the form $\left(\frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3}\right)$ where $m$ and $n$ are integers with $1\le m,n\le 29$.
 To show that every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid, we divide into cases. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(0,0)$, $(m,0)$, and $(0,n)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 10,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(0,n)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $1 \le n \le 10$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,0)$, and $(10,n)$.
 If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(0,10)$. If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(10,0)$, $(0,n - 10)$, and $(m - 10,10)$.
 If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $11 \le n \le 19$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,0)$, $(10,n - 10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $1 \le m \le 10$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(0,10)$, and $(m,10)$.
 If $10 \le m \le 19$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(0,n - 20)$, $(m - 10,10)$, and $(10,10)$. If $20 \le m \le 29$ and $20 \le n \le 29$, then we can take the points as $(m - 20,10)$, $(10,n - 20)$, and $(10,10)$.
 Thus, every point of the form $\left( \frac{m}{3}, \frac{n}{3} \right)$ can be a centroid. This means that there are $29^2=\boxed{841}$ positions for the centroid.
 *)

theorem
fixes P Q R :: "real*real"
and A :: "(real*real) set"
assumes h0 : "A = {(x,y). x in {0,0.1,..,1} & y in {0,0.1,..,1}}"
and h1 : "card A = 40"
and h2 : "{P,Q,R} ⊆ A"
and h3 : "P ≠ Q ∧ Q ≠ R ∧ R ≠ P"
and h4 : "collinear {P,Q,R} = False"
shows  "card {G. ∃ P Q R in A. P ≠ Q ∧ Q ≠ R ∧ R ≠ P ∧ collinear {P,Q,R} = False ∧ centroid {P,Q,R} = G} = 841"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a plane, there are 40 distinct points, A, such that the x and y coordinates of each point are in the set {0, 0.1, ..., 1}. Among these points, find how many unique sets of three points, P, Q, and R, can be selected such that no three points are collinear and the centroid of the triangle formed by P, Q, and R is another point, G, in the plane. The final Answer is 841.
